facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 215 of 1954 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated 23rd August 1954 of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay in Special Civil Application No. 1665 of 1954 under Article 226.

anchor.surface_text: CiviL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 215 of 1954. Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 23rd day of August 1954 of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay in Special Civil Applic

facts.text: The judgment of the Supreme Court was delivered on February 22, 1955 by SINHA J.

anchor.surface_text: 1955. February 22. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA J.-This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment and order dated the 23rd August 1954

facts.text: The facts of the case are not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: Gadag-Betgeri 1271 The facts of this case are number in dispute and may shortly be stated as follows The 1st respondent is a municipality governed by

facts.text: The 1st respondent is a municipality governed by the provisions of the Municipal Boroughs Act Bombay Act XVIII of 1925.

anchor.surface_text: The 1st respondent is a municipality governed by the provisions of the Municipal Boroughs Act  Bombay Act XVIII of 1925  which 7 hereinafter shall be referred to as the Act for the sake of brevity.

facts.text: The appellant is one of the 32 councillors constituting the municipality.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is one of the 32 companyncillors companystituting the municipality. The last general election to the municipality took place on the 7th May 1951.

facts.text: The last general election to the municipality took place on 7th May 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The last general election to the municipality took place on the 7th May 1951. The term of the companyncillors was three years companyputed from the date of the first general meetinog held after the general election

facts.text: The first general meeting after the election was held on 10th July 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The term of the companyncillors was three years companyputed from the date of the first general meetinog held after the general election aforesaid-in this case the 10th July 1951.

facts.text: In the meeting on 10th July 1951, the 4th and 5th respondents were elected President and Vice-President for three years.

anchor.surface_text: In that meeting the 4th and 5th respondents were elected President and Vice-President respectively of the municipality for a term of three years.

facts.text: The Act was amended by Bombay Act XXXV of 1954 extending the term of councillors from 3 to 4 years ending on 9th July 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was amended by Bombay Act XXXV of 1954, under which the term of office of the companyncillors was extended from 3 to 4 years ending on the 9th July 1955.

facts.text: The term of 4th and 5th respondents expired at the end of three years from 10th July 1951.

anchor.surface_text: As the term of respondents 4 and 5 aforesaid was to expire at the end of three years from the 10th July 1951 and as the term of the municipality was extended by one year under the amending Act

facts.text: The Collector called a special general meeting on 30th July 1954 to elect President and Vice-President for the remaining period.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector therefore called a special general meeting of the municipality to be held on the 30th July 1954 to elect a President and Vice-President for the remaining period of the quadrennium.

facts.text: The Prant Officer, the District Deputy Collector, was nominated by the Collector to preside over the meeting on 30th July 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector had numberinated the Prant Officer  the District Deputy Collector  to preside over that special general meeting. On the 30th July 1954 the Prant Officer under instructions from the Collector

facts.text: On 30th July 1954, the Prant Officer adjourned the meeting to 3rd August 1954 without transacting business under instructions from the Collector.

anchor.surface_text: On the 30th July 1954 the Prant Officer under instructions from the Collector adjourned the meeting to the 3rd August 1954 without transacting any business, the only item on the agenda being the election

facts.text: The 3rd respondent raised a point of order against the adjournment on 30th July 1954, which was overruled by the presiding officer.

anchor.surface_text: the 3rd respondent raised a point of order against the adjournment but the presiding officer aforesaid overruled that objection. Hence the special general meeting was held on the 3rd August 1954.

facts.text: All 32 councillors were present on 30th July 1954 and on 3rd August 1954.

anchor.surface_text: It may be added that the full strength of the municipality is 32 companyncillors all of whom were present both on the 30th July 1954 and the 3rd August 1954.

facts.text: On 3rd August 1954, the appellant raised a point of order that a President could not be elected for a term less than a year, which was overruled.

anchor.surface_text: At that meeting the appellant raised a point of order that under the provisions of the Act a President companyld number be elected for 1272 a term less than a year and that therefore the proposed election

facts.text: 13 out of 32 councillors present walked out after the point of order was overruled, including the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon 13 out of the 32 companyncillors who were present walked out on the ground that they did number propose to participate in a meeting in which the proposal was to elect a President

facts.text: The remaining 19 councillors elected the 2nd respondent as President for the remaining period of the quadrennium.

anchor.surface_text: The remaining 19 companyncillors proceeded to transact business and elected the 2nd respondent as the President, the proposal being that he should be President of the municipality for the remaining

facts.text: Immediately after, under the presidency of the newly elected President (2nd respondent), the Vice-President was elected.

anchor.surface_text: Immediately after the election of the President another meeting was held for the election of the Vice-President under the presidency of the newly elected President  the 2nd respondent .

facts.text: The appellant raised the same point of order for Vice-President election, overruled; 6 councillors including appellant walked out.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant raised the same point of order as he had done in the case of the election of the President and that was also overruled. Thereupon six of the companyncillors present including the appellant

facts.text: The remaining councillors elected the 3rd respondent as Vice-President.

anchor.surface_text: walked out and the remaining companyncillors elected the 3rd respondent as the Vice- President.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition in Bombay High Court under Art 226 for writ of quo warranto against 2nd and 3rd respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant moved the High Court of Bombay under art. 226 of the Constitution for a writ of quo warranto or any other appropriate writ or order or direction against the 2nd and 3rd respondents

facts.text: High Court dismissed the application holding the election not illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the election of the 2nd and 3rd respondents was number illegal and dismissed the application.

facts.text: High Court rejected appellant's application for leave to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant moved the High Court for leave to appeal to this companyrt but that application was rejected.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal on 3rd September 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied to this companyrt for special leave to appeal which was granted on the 3rd September 1954.

facts.text: Bombay Legislature enacted Act LIV of 1954 published on 14th October 1954.

anchor.surface_text: After the judgment of the High Court and after the grant of special leave by this companyrt, the Bombay Legislature enacted Act LIV of 1954 which was published in the Bombay Gazette on the 14th

facts.text: All 32 councillors had notice of the adjourned meeting and attended.

anchor.surface_text: It was also pointed out by the High Court that all the companyncillors companystituting the municipality had numberice of the adjourned meeting and did as a matter of fact attend that meeting

facts.text: The walking out of 13 councillors was voluntary and did not render the meeting invalid.

anchor.surface_text: But it was further companytended that the walking out of the 13 companyncillors rendered the meeting infructuous. In our opinion, such a result does number follow from the voluntary act

facts.text: Act XXXV of 1954 came into force on 11th May 1954.

anchor.surface_text: In terms the amendment in question is deemed to have companye into force on the II the May 1954 1282 on which date the amending Act XXXV of 1954 had companye into force.

facts.text: Supreme Court affirms the orders of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly affirm the orders of the High Court, though number for the same reasons.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even assuming invalid adjournment of 30th July, 3rd Aug was fresh meeting called by Collector; notice provisions directory, cured by s57, no prejudice shown as all councillors present; voluntary walkout does not invalidate; public presence not required

holdings.text: Provisions of section 35(3) are directory and not mandatory

holdings.text: Retrospective amendments apply to pending proceedings without need for express words if language clear

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clear language suffices; precedents like Singer and Mukerjee support; no implied saving clause; gives full effect to legislative intent covering all elections post-date

holdings.text: Orders of the High Court affirmed

precedents.citation: The King v. The General Commissioners of Income- tax for Southampton Ex parte W. M. Singer 1

anchor.surface_text: The King v. The General Commissioners of Income- tax for Southampton Ex parte W. M. Singer 1 ,- I cannot accept the contention of the applicant that an enactment can only take away vested rights of action for which legal proceedings have been commenced if there are in the enactment express words to that effect.

precedents.case_name: The King v General Commissioners of Income Tax for Southampton ex parte WM Singer
precedents.cited_proposition: Retrospective effect of statute can extend to pending proceedings if clear language is used, without needing express words about pending proceedings
precedents.cited_holding: I cannot accept the contention of the applicant that an enactment can only take away vested rights of action for which legal proceedings have been commenced if there are in the enactment express words to that effect. There is no authority for this proposition [...] But it is necessary that clear language should be used to make the retrospective effect applicable to proceedings commenced before the passing of the statute.

precedents.citation: Mukerjee, Official Receiver v. Ramratan Kuer 1

anchor.surface_text: Mukerjee, Official Receiver v. Ramratan Kuer 1 , which is clearly in point. In that case while an appeal had been pending before the Judicial Committee the amending Act had been passed clearly showing that the Act was retrospective in the sense that it applied to all cases of a particular description, without reference to pending litigation.

precedents.case_name: Mukerjee Official Receiver v Ramratan Kuer
precedents.cited_proposition: Retrospective amending Act applies to pending litigation if it clearly applies to all cases of a particular description without saving for pending cases
precedents.cited_holding: while an appeal had been pending before the Judicial Committee the amending Act had been passed clearly showing that the Act was retrospective in the sense that it applied to all cases of a particular description, without reference to pending litigation [...] if any saving were to be implied in favour of pending proceedings, then the provisions of the statute would largely be rendered nugatory.
